articles.headline: Sleeping on America’s Doorstep: A Dispatch From the Border
articles.snippet: For families waiting to request asylum in the United States, a small patch of ground is now their bedroom, washroom, school, kitchen and playground.
articles.abstract: For families waiting to request asylum in the United States, a small patch of ground is now their bedroom, washroom, school, kitchen and playground.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Mexico — It was dinner time at the door to the United States, and on a spit of floor separating Mexico from Arizona, several families set out their plates, ripping tortillas and spooning rice and trying to ignore the indignities of life on the move.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Sides With American Express on Merchant Fees
articles.snippet: In a test of antitrust law, the justices ruled 5 to 4 that the company could use contracts to stop merchants from steering consumers to other cards.
articles.abstract: In a test of antitrust law, the justices ruled 5 to 4 that the company could use contracts to stop merchants from steering consumers to other cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American Express did not violate the antitrust laws by insisting in its contracts with merchants that they do nothing to encourage patrons to use other cards, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday.

articles.headline: How China Got Sri Lanka to Cough Up a Port
articles.snippet: A Times investigation into Sri Lanka’s handover of its Hambantota Port starkly illustrates how China turned an ally’s struggles to its strategic advantage.
articles.abstract: A Times investigation into Sri Lanka’s handover of its Hambantota Port starkly illustrates how China turned an ally’s struggles to its strategic advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMBANTOTA, Sri Lanka — Every time Sri Lanka’s president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, turned to his Chinese allies for loans and assistance with an ambitious port project, the answer was yes.

articles.headline: Border Officials Suspend Handing Over Migrant Families to Prosecutors
articles.snippet: Effectively, the Customs and Border Protection commissioner’s decision revives a “catch and release” approach for most families crossing the Mexican border illegally.
articles.abstract: Effectively, the Customs and Border Protection commissioner’s decision revives a “catch and release” approach for most families crossing the Mexican border illegally.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — The nation’s top border security official said Monday that his agency has temporarily stopped handing over migrant adults who cross the Mexican border with children for prosecution, undercutting claims by other Trump administration officials that “zero tolerance” for illegal immigration is still in place.
articles.byline: By Ron Nixon, Erica L. Green and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Democrats Confront Democrats Over How to Confront Trump
articles.snippet: Progressives’ public shaming of Trump administration members in recent days has opened a rift in the party over whether to embrace or discourage such behavior.
articles.abstract: Progressives’ public shaming of Trump administration members in recent days has opened a rift in the party over whether to embrace or discourage such behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than two years, Democrats have struggled with how aggressively to confront Donald J. Trump, a political opponent unlike any other: Should they attack him over his hard-line policies; his inflammatory, norm-breaking conduct; or some combination of both?

articles.headline: Top Tech Companies Met With Intelligence Officials to Discuss Midterms
articles.snippet: A meeting in May was meant for a discussion of foreign meddling in this year’s midterm elections. But some tech officials left frustrated.
articles.abstract: A meeting in May was meant for a discussion of foreign meddling in this year’s midterm elections. But some tech officials left frustrated.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Eight of the tech industry’s most influential companies, in anticipation of a repeat of the Russian meddling that occurred during the 2016 presidential campaign, met with United States intelligence officials last month to discuss preparations for this year’s midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: G.E. to Spin Off Health Care Division as Part of Major Reshaping
articles.snippet: The move comes as General Electric’s chief executive, John Flannery, focuses the company on its aviation, power and renewable energy activities.
articles.abstract: The move comes as General Electric’s chief executive, John Flannery, focuses the company on its aviation, power and renewable energy activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: When John L. Flannery took over as the chief executive of General Electric last August, he declared that he would not be nostalgic about the industrial giant’s storied past when reshaping the company for the future.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Trump Threatens Harley-Davidson, Saying It ‘Surrendered’
articles.snippet: President Trump took aim at one of his favorite American manufacturers a day after it said it would shift some production overseas to avoid retaliatory tariffs.
articles.abstract: President Trump took aim at one of his favorite American manufacturers a day after it said it would shift some production overseas to avoid retaliatory tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump lashed out at one of his favorite American manufacturers on Tuesday, criticizing Harley-Davidson over its plans to move some of its motorcycle production abroad and threatening it with punitive taxes in return.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Stacy M. Brown

articles.headline: Supreme Court Backs Anti-Abortion Pregnancy Centers in Free Speech Case
articles.snippet: The centers had argued that a California law violated their free speech rights by forcing them to convey messages at odds with their beliefs.
articles.abstract: The centers had argued that a California law violated their free speech rights by forcing them to convey messages at odds with their beliefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ruling for opponents of abortion on free speech grounds, the Supreme Court said on Tuesday that the State of California may not require religiously oriented “crisis pregnancy centers” to supply women with information about how to end their pregnancies.

articles.headline: Trump’s Travel Ban Is Upheld by Supreme Court
articles.snippet: In a 5-to-4 vote, the Supreme Court ruled that President Trump acted lawfully in imposing limits on travel from several predominantly Muslim countries.
articles.abstract: In a 5-to-4 vote, the Supreme Court ruled that President Trump acted lawfully in imposing limits on travel from several predominantly Muslim countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court upheld President Trump’s ban on travel from several predominantly Muslim countries, delivering to the president on Tuesday a political victory and an endorsement of his power to control immigration at a time of political upheaval about the treatment of migrants at the Mexican border.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: As Trade Fight Looms, China Turns Censors on Its Own Policies
articles.snippet: Officials are suppressing media mentions of Made in China 2025, the country’s three-year-old, very public plan to become a high-tech superpower.
articles.abstract: Officials are suppressing media mentions of Made in China 2025, the country’s three-year-old, very public plan to become a high-tech superpower.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China’s government, which tirelessly suppresses critical voices, unwanted ideologies and subversive memes, has turned its censors against an unlikely target: its own economic policies.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Li Yuan
